step1.description: Take tests to deeply understand your company's values and culture, forming a basis to select the right fit.

step4.title: Search & Screen
step4.description: Use advanced filters to search for candidates by industry, skills, and experience.

step5.title: Review & Interview

step6.title: Hire & Onboard

barrettTest.title: Barrett Values Assessment
barrettTest.subtitle: Discover the values that drive you and your organization.
barrettTest.step1Content: Welcome to the Barrett Values Assessment. This tool will help you gain deeper insight into your personal values and your organization's culture. You will be guided through a 3-step process. Click 'Next' to begin.
barrettTest.step2Content: From the list below, select 10 values that most represent who you are. These are not values you think you should have, but values that truly define you.
barrettTest.step3Content: Now, select 10 values that you believe best describe your organization's current culture.
barrettTest.step4Content: Finally, select 10 values that you would like to see in your organization's future culture.
barrettTest.step5Content: Thank you for completing the assessment. Below is a summary of your selected values. This report can help you and your organization understand your cultural alignment and identify areas for growth.

goldenCircle.title: Find Your 'Why'
goldenCircle.description: The Golden Circle is a model by Simon Sinek that helps organizations articulate their purpose. By starting with 'Why', you can inspire action and attract employees and customers who share your core beliefs.

why.title: Why
why.description: This is the core belief of the business. It's not about making moneyâthat's a result. The 'Why' is the purpose, cause, or belief that inspires you to do what you do.
why.formPrompt: What is your purpose, cause, or belief? Why does your organization exist?

how.title: How
how.description: These are the specific actions taken to realize the 'Why'. It's your Unique Selling Proposition (USP), the things that differentiate you from the competition.
how.formPrompt: How do you do what you do? What specific actions do you take to realize your purpose?

what.title: What
what.description: This is what the company doesâthe products it sells or the services it offers. It is the most tangible and easily identified aspect.
what.formPrompt: What do you do? What products do you sell or services do you offer?

goldenCircle.ctaDescription: Use the Golden Circle model to clarify your message and build a stronger, more authentic brand.
goldenCircle.note: (This is a conceptual tool for strategic planning.)
goldenCircle.resultsDescription: Here is the result of your brainstorming session. Use this to clarify your purpose and inspire action.

lessons.title: Why do Vietnamese workers love singing karaoke at home?
Vietnamese cooking culture (fish sauce, etc.) and flavor conflicts in dorms.
The Vietnamese habit of communal living vs. Japanese privacy.
Social media habits: livestreaming, posting photos - risks and etiquette.
Days off: a preference for gatherings, food, and karaoke.
Punctuality: Vietnamese habits vs. Japanese expectations.
Familiar address terms vs. Japanese Keigo (honorifics).
Overtime (ZangyÅ): Why do Vietnamese workers like to work extra hours?
Relationship with Japanese bosses: differences in hierarchy culture.
The habit of sending most of their salary home: reasons & impacts.
Family life in Vietnam: Why do they rely on remittances?
The habit of extreme frugality in Japan.
Community comparisons: Who sends more money, who works more hours.
The pressure to 'get rich quick' in Japan.
The pressure of repaying loans for going abroad to work.
Preferring to live with compatriots: A cultural perspective.
The importance of the compatriot community.
Health issues: working too much, neglecting self-care.
Prioritizing overtime over learning Japanese: long-term consequences.
The mindset of 'self-sacrifice for the family'.

article.title: How to Write a Compelling Japanese CV to Impress Recruiters
article.excerpt: A well-prepared CV (å±¥æ­´æ¸ - rirekisho) is the first and most crucial step to opening the door to your dream job in Japan. It's not just a summary of your experience, but your very first introduction to a potential employer.
article.author: HelloJob Team

content.p1: In a competitive landscape, a professional, clean, and comprehensive CV will make you stand out. It's essential to adhere to the common rules and standards of a Japanese CV, from the layout and use of honorifics (keigo) to the profile picture.
content.p2: The Specified Skilled Worker (ç¹å®æè½ - Tokutei Ginou) visa is a new residency status for foreign workers in Japan, introduced by the Japanese government in April 2019. The main purpose of this program is to address serious labor shortages in specific industrial fields in Japan. This program is divided into two main categories:
content.listHtml:
• Specified Skilled Worker (i) (Tokutei Ginou 1): For workers with a certain level of skill and specialized knowledge, who can work immediately without much training. The maximum period of stay is 5 years, and family members are not allowed to accompany them.
  • Specified Skilled Worker (ii) (Tokutei Ginou 2): For workers with high-level skills and professional expertise. After completing the Type 1 program, workers can take an exam to advance to Type 2 to stay in Japan long-term, with opportunities to apply for permanent residency and sponsor family members.
content.p3: To participate in the Specified Skilled Worker program, workers need to meet basic conditions: Be 18 years of age or older, pass the Japanese-Language Proficiency Test (JLPT) at level N4 or equivalent exams like the JFT-Basic, and pass the skills proficiency test for their registered industry.

opportunities.title: Caregiver
opportunities.description: Caring for the elderly at a nursing home in Kanagawa. The job includes assisting with daily living activities, health care, and recreational activities. Applicants are required to have a nursing certificate and work experience.
requirements: At least 1 year of experience in the caregiving industry.
Japanese language proficiency equivalent to N4 or higher.
Good health, free from infectious diseases.
Responsible and passionate about caring for the elderly.
benefits: Basic salary from 180,000 JPY/month, excluding overtime.
Support for housing, dormitory near the workplace.
Full insurance coverage according to Japanese law.
Opportunities for advanced training and visa renewal.

opportunities.title: Agricultural Worker
opportunities.description: Working at a farm that grows organic vegetables using Japanese technology. The work includes planting, caring for, harvesting, and packaging products. No experience is required; training will be provided.
requirements: Hardworking, diligent, and willing to learn.
No experience required, training will be provided from the beginning.
benefits: Opportunity to learn advanced Japanese agricultural techniques.

hofstede.title: Hofstede Culture Scan
hofstede.description: Geert Hofstede's model of national culture is a framework for cross-cultural communication, describing the effects of a society's culture on the values of its members, and how these values relate to behavior.

dimensions.name: Power Distance
dimensions.description: The extent to which the less powerful members of organizations and institutions (like the family) accept and expect that power is distributed unequally.

dimensions.name: Individualism vs. Collectivism
dimensions.description: The degree to which people in a society are integrated into groups.

dimensions.name: Masculinity vs. Femininity
dimensions.description: A preference in society for achievement, heroism, assertiveness and material rewards for success (Masculinity) versus a preference for cooperation, modesty, caring for the weak and quality of life (Femininity).

dimensions.name: Uncertainty Avoidance
dimensions.description: The extent to which a society deals with the fact that the future can never be known.

dimensions.name: Long-Term vs. Short-Term Orientation
dimensions.description: How every society has to maintain some links with its own past while dealing with the challenges of the present and future.

dimensions.name: Indulgence vs. Restraint
dimensions.description: The extent to which people try to control their desires and impulses.

hofstede.ctaDescription: Use the tools on the official Hofstede Insights website to compare countries and better understand cultural differences.
hofstede.note: (This tool is available on the Hofstede Insights website.)
